channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Shifts Dynamic of War
item.description: President Biden met with European leaders in Brussels to reinforce solidarity against Russia’s invasion and proposed excluding Russia from the G20. Ukraine said it had destroyed a Russian naval ship.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: ‘A Frightening Repeat’: Ukrainian World War II Survivors Face Conflict Again
item.description: Nearly 80 years after Ukraine emerged from a devastating world war that killed more than five million of its people, Russia’s invasion has stirred memories that the country had struggled to overcome.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Borys Zabarko, a survivor of World War II, fled his home in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, and is now in Stuttgart, Germany.

item.title: Belarusian Exiles in Ukraine Join the Fight Against Russia’s Invasion
item.description: Eager, but ill equipped, some of Belarus’s exiles have formed a battalion in their host country, saying its fight against Vladimir Putin’s domination is the same as their homeland’s.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins

item.title: How One Month of War in Ukraine Ground to a Bloody Stalemate
item.description: In four weeks, huge numbers of civilians have been bombed and displaced, but Russia has so far achieved almost none of its military objectives, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke from a Russian strike in Kyiv on Wednesday. Cities and towns across the country are being bombarded daily by Russian forces.

item.title: Ethiopia Declares ‘Humanitarian Truce’ in War-Ravaged Tigray Region
item.description: The conflict, now lasting 17 months, has left thousands dead, millions displaced and hindered aid from reaching those going hungry in the country’s northern region.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Simon Marks
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bus carrying civilians passing a destroyed tank outside Mekelle, the capital of Ethiopia’s Tigray region, in June 2021.

item.title: Fed Up With Deadly Propaganda, Some Russian Journalists Quit
item.description: At least four state television employees have publicly resigned, citing regret for their roles in promoting false narratives about Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: The Ostankino TV center in Moscow earlier this month.

item.title: A Bomb Crater as Business Partner for a Pit Stop on an Afghan Highway
item.description: Along a lonely stretch of what was once the most dangerous road in Afghanistan, everyone slows down when they reach Hafiz Qadim’s mud brick shop. It’s not the food. Or the gas. It’s the big hole.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Yaqoob Akbary
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hafiz Qadim waiting for traveling customers to stop and purchase gas, water and snacks at his newly built shop along the Kabul–Kandahar Highway in Afghanistan’s Zabul Province.

item.title: China Eastern Pilots Were Experienced, Adding to Mystery of Crash
item.description: Two industry veterans were at the controls of Flight 5735, which took a sudden dive in good weather. At the crash site in southern China, search crews found wing and engine parts on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: A China Eastern plane landing in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: Australia Agrees to Let New Zealand Resettle Offshore Refugees
item.description: Under the arrangement, first offered in 2013, New Zealand will take in 150 refugees a year for three years from Australia’s widely criticized detention system.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The East Lorengau Refugee Transit Center on Manus Island, Papua New Guinea, in 2018, in a photo provided by Aziz Abdul, a refugee who spent four years in detention on Manus.

item.title: 4 Die After Falling From Balcony in Swiss Resort Town
item.description: The police, who are investigating the cause, said the people were most likely members of the same family, including an 8-year-old girl, her parents and aunt. A boy, 15, was in the hospital in critical condition.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Police officers taking samples on a balcony from which five people fell, with four of them dying, in Montreux, Switzerland, on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Officials Meet With Brittney Griner in Russia
item.description: Some former hostages question whether the family should remain silent, saying pressure campaigns can work.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz, Jonathan Abrams and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, one of the most prominent and decorated athletes in American sports, is languishing in a Russian cell on drug charges.

item.title: Taliban Renege on Promise to Open Afghan Girls’ Schools
item.description: The schools were supposed to reopen this week, and the reversal could threaten aid because international officials had made girls’ education a condition for greater assistance.
item.dc:creator: Safiullah Padshah and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Ahmad Sahel Arman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Girls attending a class after their school briefly reopened in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Wednesday, before being quickly shut down again.

item.title: In Asia, Covid-19 Rules Fall Away, With a Big Caveat
item.description: Daily life in the region was once regulated by a snarl of virus restrictions. That is changing fast — except in mainland China, which is still rolling out lockdowns.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez, Mike Ives and Victoria Kim
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Ezra Acayan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Quiapo shopping district in Manila, Philippines, on Friday.

item.title: China and Solomon Islands Draft Secret Security Pact, Raising Alarm in the Pacific
item.description: The leaked agreement, if signed, could help the Chinese Navy block shipping routes that played a vital role in World War II.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Li Keqiang, left, the Chinese premier, and Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare of the Solomon Islands reviewing an honor guard during a ceremony in Beijing in 2019.

item.title: British Rainfall Records Extended Back to 1836 Thanks to Covid Lockdowns
item.description: As Britain went into its first Covid lockdown, a scientist asked for help transcribing rainfall records spanning three centuries. Thousands of people online answered the call.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Heritage Image Partnership Ltd., via Alamy
item.media:description: A 19th-century illustration of a rainy day at London Bridge by Godefroy Durand.

item.title: In Putin’s Misbegotten War, NATO Sees Danger and Opportunity
item.description: The 30-nation alliance had regarded Russia’s invasion of Ukraine as unstoppable just a month ago, but now sees the possibility of a Russian quagmire there.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: The NATO summit meeting in Brussels on Thursday.

item.title: Methane Leaks Plague New Mexico Oil and Gas Wells
item.description: An analysis found leaks of methane, a potent greenhouse gas, from oil and gas drilling in the Permian Basin were many times higher than government estimates.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Joel Angel Juarez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil pump site within the Permian Basin in Loco Hills, N.M.

item.title: Ukraine Tries to Seize Momentum With Claims of Counteroffensive
item.description: The picture on the ground is muddy and it’s unclear how much territory Ukraine has gained back. But its announcement of a counteroffensive has enhanced the notion that it is taking the fight to the enemy.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lt. Tetiana Chornovol, commander of an anti-tank missile unit, on the outskirts of Kyiv earlier this month.

item.title: Ukraine’s troops begin counteroffensive that alters shape of the battle with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers with anti-tank weapons near the front lines north of Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Global Diplomacy in Brussels
item.description: President Biden said Russia should be removed from the G20.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Biden talked with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau as G7 leaders met at NATO Headquarters in Brussels on Thursday.

item.title: U.N. General Assembly Vote Further Isolates Russia on Ukraine War
item.description: Syria, North Korea, Eritrea and Belarus voted against the resolution, joining Russia, which called the measure “pseudo-humanitarian.”
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: One month after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the United Nations passed a resolution demanding an end to the war.

item.title: Most in U.S. Say Biden ‘Not Tough Enough’ on Russia, Poll Finds
item.description: The national mood has made a sudden swung toward punishing Russia, the poll shows, putting more pressure on the president as he treads a careful course on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.media:description: President Biden at the G7 meeting in Brussels on Thursday.

item.title: Biden and His Allies Vow to Take a Tougher Stance on Russia
item.description: In a day of summit meetings, President Biden and his counterparts faced the prospect of Russia using weapons of mass destruction. Mr. Biden said the United States would admit 100,000 Ukrainian refugees.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: President Biden talking with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada before posing for a Group of 7 leaders’ photo in Brussels on Thursday.

item.title: Why the U.S. Was Wrong About Ukraine and the Afghan War
item.description: U.S. intelligence agencies thought the Afghan military would last longer and predicted Kyiv would fall faster, showing the difficulty of assessing fighting spirit.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A class teaching civilians combat skills this month in Lutsk, Ukraine.

item.title: E.U. Takes Aim at Big Tech’s Power With Landmark Digital Act
item.description: The Digital Markets Act is the most sweeping legislation to regulate tech since a European privacy law was passed in 2018.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:description: Margrethe Vestager and Thierry Breton, top European officials who helped lead the push on the Digital Markets Act to regulate tech power.

item.title: NATO to Provide Ukraine Training for a Possible Chemical or Nuclear Attack
item.description: The alliance will offer Ukraine detection equipment, protection and medical support, as well as training for decontamination and crisis management.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Jens Stoltenberg, NATO’s secretary general, at a Latvian base this month. On Thursday, he said NATO would help Ukraine prepare to respond to any possible chemical or biological weapons attack.

item.title: United States Will Welcome Up to 100,000 Ukrainian Refugees
item.description: With European nations under stress from three million new refugees, the United States said it would substantially increase admissions of people fleeing Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A refugee family from Ukraine in Palanca, Moldova. U.S. officials expect that most Ukrainian refugees will want to stay in Europe, close to their homes and adult male family members, who have been prohibited from leaving the country.

item.title: Zelensky Calls on Biden and NATO Members to Do More to Help Ukraine
item.description: In a video address to a closed-door session of the military alliance, President Volodymyr Zelensky warned that Russia “does not intend to stop in Ukraine,” according to his government’s transcript.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, via EPA - Shutterstock

item.title: Russian Crew on a Superyacht Possibly Linked to Putin Have Left Their Jobs, Workers Say
item.description: U.S. officials have said the Scheherezade, which is dry-docked in Italy, could be owned by the Russian leader.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: The superyacht Scheherazade in dry dock in the port of Marina di Carrara in central Italy on Thursday.

item.title: Singapore to Ease Some Covid Restrictions
item.description: The prime minister said that the change represented a “major step,” but that the country would “stop short of a complete opening up.”
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: An open-air area in Singapore last month.

item.title: China’s Push to Isolate Taiwan Demands U.S. Action, Report Says
item.description: Chinese officials are ramping up a campaign to force United Nations agencies, governments, companies and even schools to say Taiwan is a part of China.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Amy Qin
item.category: German Marshall Fund of the United States
item.media:description: Taiwanese flags fly in Taipei. More than ever, many of the island’s residents identify as solely Taiwanese, and not Chinese.

item.title: Poland Wins European Tree of the Year After Russia Is Banned
item.description: After Russia was banned from the European Tree of the Year competition, organizers reflected on how a celebration of trees became tangled up in global politics.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Poland became the winner of the European Tree of the Year competition after Russia’s submission was disqualified after its invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Ukrainian Forces Claim to Destroy a Russian Landing Ship
item.description: The destruction of the ship would be a success for the Ukrainians as they seek to keep Russia from reinforcing and resupplying its forces as they struggle to gain momentum.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Haley Willis
item.media:description: Smoke was visible near a seaport in Berdyansk, Ukraine, on Thursday after the Ukrainian Navy reported that it had sunk the Russian ship Orsk in the Sea of Azov.

item.title: Distorted Reality
item.description: Senate Republicans are painting a false portrait of Ketanji Brown Jackson.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson at the confirmation hearing yesterday.

item.title: What’s in North Korea’s Weapons Arsenal?
item.description: The expansion of the arsenal has become a growing threat to the United States and allies in the region.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media showed missiles during a military parade at Kim Il-sung Square in Pyongyang, the capital, in 2021.

item.title: BA.2 Omicron Subvariant Driving Most Global Cases, W.H.O. Says
item.description: Globally, BA.2 made up about 86 percent of cases reported to the W.H.O. between Feb. 16 and March 17, the agency said in a report on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A Covid-19 patient at Tor Vergata Hospital in Rome.

item.title: ‘Is There Shooting Here?’ Ukrainians Find Refuge in Moldova
item.description: Moldova, one of Europe’s smallest and poorest countries, has taken in more than 100,000 refugees from Ukraine. But Moldova’s ability to protect them is reaching a breaking point.
item.dc:creator: Emily Rhyne, Simon Ostrovsky and Ben Laffin

item.title: With U.S. Focus on Ukraine, North Korea Launches a Powerful New ICBM
item.description: It was the country’s first long-range ballistic missile test since 2017, and it raised the specter of intensified provocations and threats on the Korean Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: News coverage in Seoul on Thursday, after North Korea carried out its latest missile launch.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: NATO bolsters its defenses.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Supreme Court of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Jacques Boissinot/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Canadian soldiers on their way to Latvia as NATO strengthens its presence in Central and Eastern Europe.

item.title: Government Struggles to Respond to Flooding in Australia
item.description: Civilians were largely left to rescue one another as a natural disaster struck Australia. It shows how the authorities are struggling to respond to climate-fueled calamities.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Matthew Abbott
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chelsea Mackenzie-Saul and her daughter at the flood-damaged house of Ms. Mackenzie-Saul’s mother in Lismore, Australia, earlier this month.

item.title: U.S. Makes Contingency Plans in Case Russia Uses Its Most Powerful Weapons
item.description: A team of national security officials has been assigned to sketch out responses if President Vladimir V. Putin unleashes chemical, biological or nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt, Helene Cooper and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Biden arrived in Brussels on Wednesday, where he will meet with NATO leaders.

item.title: As Biden Visits Europe Over Crisis, NATO Says It’s Doubling Eastern Flank Forces
item.description: The alliance also said it would assist Ukraine because of chemical, biological and nuclear threats posed by Russia in the month-old invasion.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, David E. Sanger and Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: President Biden and Prime Minister Alexander De Croo of Belgium in Brussels on Wednesday. Mr. Biden visited Europe for an extraordinary strategy session with the NATO alliance.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: NATO Boosts Its Eastern Presence
item.description: Plus Asia’s disappearing Covid rules and the Taliban’s reversal on girls’ schools.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: German soldiers attached to the Lithuania-based NATO battlegroup undergoing training this month.

item.title: With Eye to Russia, Biden Administration Asks Companies to Report Cyberattacks
item.description: A new law requires companies to tell the federal government about hacks, but the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency still has to work out the details of what must be reported.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:description: Fuel storage tanks connected to the Colonial Pipeline system in Baltimore. A cyberattack disrupted the pipeline’s operations last year.

item.title: The U.S. Government Accuses Russian Forces of War Crimes
item.description: In a statement, the U.S. secretary of state, Antony J. Blinken, cited the destruction of “apartment buildings, schools, hospitals, critical infrastructure, civilian vehicles, shopping centers, and ambulances.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firemen and emergency workers on Monday at the ruins of the Retroville Mall, a shopping center in Kyiv, the capital, after a powerful explosion.

item.title: Many Asian and Pacific countries are swiftly easing Covid rules, with one big exception.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez, Mike Ives, Victoria Kim and Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Ezra Acayan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crowds at the Manila Zoo last week.

item.title: U.N. Investigator Accuses Israel of Apartheid, Citing Permanence of Occupation
item.description: Strongly denied by Israel and its supporters, the claim is the first time that a U.N.-appointed rapporteur has accused Israel of apartheid in such an unequivocal way.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A U.N.-appointed investigator joined other rights watchdogs that have sought to recast the Israeli-Palestinian conflict as a struggle for equal rights instead of a territorial dispute.

item.title: Julian Assange Marries Stella Moris in a British Prison
item.description: The wedding took place at Belmarsh Prison, where Mr. Assange has been held since 2019. Supporters of the couple were encouraged to attend a “solidarity vigil” outside the facility.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Stella Moris cut a wedding cake given to her by supporters at Belmarsh Prison in southeast London, where she married the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange on Wednesday.

item.title: Top Virologist Who Visited a Wuhan Market in 2014 Said He Found
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: U.S. Capitol to Reopen Tours Next Week
item.description: Tours of the Capitol were suspended for about two years over the pandemic and security concerns related to the Jan. 6 riot.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. Capitol in Washington on Monday.

item.title: Israel Blocked Sale of Pegasus Spyware to Ukraine and Estonia
item.description: The Eastern European countries had sought to buy Pegasus, spyware made by an Israeli firm, to carry out intelligence operations against Russia, according to people with knowledge of the discussions.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Mark Mazzetti
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine criticized Israel for not providing his country with the Iron Dome antimissile system and other defensive weapons during a speech on Sunday.

item.title: NATO Doubles Troop Presence in Eastern Europe Ahead of Summit
item.description: The alliance’s secretary general announced the deployment of new battlegroups in Bulgaria, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia. NATO has four others in the region.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: German soldiers attached to the Lithuania-based NATO battlegroup undergoing training this month.

item.title: Evan Neumann, Accused in Capitol Riot, Granted Asylum in Belarus
item.description: Evan Neumann, who is wanted by the F.B.I. on charges including assaulting police officers at the Jan. 6 riot in Washington, has been granted asylum in Belarus, officials told state media.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Valeriya Safronova
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters stormed the Capitol in Washington on Jan. 6, 2021. Mr. Neumann has denied striking officers or committing any other crimes during the riot.

item.title: Could a Crackdown on Oligarchs Help Ukraine?
item.description: Russian oligarchs helped boost Vladimir V. Putin’s influence in the West. Can sanctions turn that pressure back on him?
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: A group of squatters on the balcony of a mansion in London’s Belgrave Square earlier this month.

item.title: Ukraine War Ignites Israeli Debate Over Purpose of a Jewish State
item.description: Most Ukrainians seeking refuge in Israel are non-Jews. Some Israelis see a moral imperative to take them in, but others see a threat to the country’s Jewish character.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lida Stryzhkovl, from Kyiv, Ukraine, and her grandson, Dima, waiting at Ben-Gurion Airport's train station, on their way to Beersheba, where a relative lives.
